questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of malaise, dysuria, blurred vision, and a painful, itchy rash. The rash began on her chest and face and spread to her limbs, palms, and soles. One week ago, she was diagnosed with trigeminal neuralgia and started on a new medicine. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F) and pulse is 110/min. Physical examination shows conjunctival injection and ulceration on the tongue and palate. There is no lymphadenopathy. Examination of the skin shows confluent annular, erythematous macules, bullae, and desquamation of the palms and soles. The epidermis separates when the skin is lightly stroked. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bullous pemphigoid classically affects older adults, manifesting with tense bullae (negative Nikolsky sign) on the skin, without involvement of the oral or ocular mucosa. Furthermore, there is no known association between carbamazepine and bullous pemphigoid.
Image Description:

Tense blisters, erosions, and crusts on erythematous skin are visible on the knee.

These findings are consistent with bullous pemphigoid.

B) CORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a rare yet serious adverse effect of carbamazepine, as well as many other drugs (e.g., phenytoin, lamotrigine, and phenobarbital). It initially manifests with fever and flu-like symptoms (e.g., chills and myalgias). The classic cutaneous manifestation consists of painful, erythematous, annular macules with pruritic centers that begin on the face and thorax and spread symmetrically to the extremities, which are accompanied by stomatitis, mucositis, conjunctivitis, and/or corneal ulceration. Physical examination often shows a positive Nikolsky sign, as seen in this patient. The skin desquamation may progress to involve large areas of the skin. Involvement of > 30% of the total body surface area is referred to as toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), whereas involvement of 10–30% is considered SJS/TEN overlap. Treatment of SJS includes discontinuation of the offending drug and supportive therapy similar to that of burns (fluid resuscitation, wound management, antibiotics in case of infection). Cyclosporine may slow SJS progression.
Image Description:

Back, buttocks, thighs, and legs of an 8-month-old infant 2 weeks after primary vaccination

Irregularly shaped, partially confluent, erythematous macules with bullae are visible.

Patient history suggests Stevens-Johnson syndrome triggered by vaccination.

C) INCORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris (PV) classically manifests with cutaneous flaccid bullae that can affect the oral mucosa but spare the palms and soles. The bullae have a positive Nikolsky sign and tend to rupture easily, leading to significant pain and bleeding; however, pruritus would not be expected following rupture. Moreover, it would be very rare for PV to arise following treatment with carbamazepine.
Image Description:

Multiple ruptured blisters with surrounding erythema are visible. A single intact blister can be seen in the center of the image.

This finding is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris, but histopathology is required to confirm the diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Erythema multiforme (EM) is most commonly associated with herpes simplex virus or Mycoplasma pneumoniae infections but can also rarely occur as an adverse effect of carbamazepine. EM causes erythematous, target-shaped lesions. Erythema multiforme major, a subform of EM, manifests with mucosal involvement and systemic symptoms such as fever. EM lesions are usually painless and classically arise as a symmetrical distribution on the acral and extensor surfaces of the extremities, which then spreads proximally and may include the palms and soles.
Image Description:

Multiple circular lesions with a central papule and raised edges (also called “target lesions”), surrounded by a lighter edematous area, are visible on the anterior aspect of the thighs.

This is the typical appearance of erythema multiforme.

E) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced lupus is associated with a variety of drugs, including sulfa-drugs, antiepileptics (e.g. carbamazepine or phenytoin), and TNF-α blockers. The condition initially manifests with systemic symptoms (e,g., fevers, myalgias, and arthralgias) and may cause serositis (e.g. pleuritis and pericarditis) or hematologic abnormalities (e.g., anemia, leukopenia, and/or thrombocytopenia). Cutaneous manifestations are less common in drug-induced lupus than in idiopathic lupus. When present, the rash associated with drug-induced lupus takes the form of large, erythematous patches rather than the bullae with a positive Nikolsky sign seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) is a rare drug-induced hypersensitivity reaction that is caused by a variety of drugs, including carbamazepine. While it manifests with fever, affected patients also have facial edema and lymphadenopathy, neither of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, the rash is usually a morbilliform eruption that quickly evolves into a diffuse, confluent rash involving > 50% of the body surface area. The presence of bullae and a positive Nikolsky sign are inconsistent with DRESS syndrome.
Image Description:

Facial erythema and edema are visible, sparing only the periorbital region. The erythema, especially around the mouth, has an eczematous appearance.

Facial edema is a common clinical feature in DRESS, but also occurs in many other conditions. The triad of high fever, extensive skin rash, and organ involvement should raise concern for DRESS.

G) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) is caused by S. aureus exfoliative toxin. SSSS manifests with systemic symptoms (e.g., fever and malaise) and diffuse, flaccid bullae along the flexural surfaces, hands, feet, and buttock; the Nikolsky sign is typically positive. However, SSSS is most often seen in the pediatric population following a staphylococcal infection (e.g., impetigo), which this adult patient has no history of. Finally, mucosal involvement, as seen in this patient, would be very unusual.
Image Description:

Perioral, cervical and axillary reddening of the skin is visible, resulting in a scalded appearance on this child's face. In some areas, the superficial epidermal layer is detached (e.g., on the chin). On the right side of the neck, several flaccid blisters can be seen. The lips appear dry, with several rhagades in the corners of the mouth.
questions.hint: The first-line therapy for trigeminal neuralgia is carbamazepine, which is the most likely trigger of this patient's mucocutaneous immune reaction.

questions.text: One week after starting a new medication, a 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of a painful, blistering rash. She has a history of bipolar disorder. Her temperature is 39°C (102°F). Physical examination shows numerous coalescing bullae with epidermal detachment covering the face, trunk, and extremities. There are hemorrhagic erosions on the hard palate and buccal mucosa. When lateral pressure is applied to healthy-appearing skin at the edge of a bulla, a blister starts to form. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Quetiapine is an atypical antipsychotic that is used with first-line mood stabilizers to treat refractory bipolar disorder. However, cases of SJS attributed to quetiapine therapy have not been reported. More common adverse effects of quetiapine therapy include hyperprolactinemia, weight gain, hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, prolonged QT interval, and extrapyramidal symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is sometimes used in conjunction with other agents to treat refractory bipolar disorder. However, cases of SJS attributed to topiramate therapy have not been reported. More common adverse effects of topiramate therapy include glaucoma, weight loss, nephrolithiasis, and cognitive impairment.

C) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is used to treat bipolar disorder. However, valproic acid is an extremely rare cause of SJS. More common adverse effects of valproic acid therapy include hepatic necrosis, pancreatitis, drug interactions due to CYP450 inhibition, weight gain, and gastrointestinal distress.

D) CORRECT:

Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is used to treat bipolar disorder. It is one of the most commonly implicated triggers of SJS. Most cases of SJS develop within 2–8 weeks of initiating the offending medication. The risk of developing SJS induced by lamotrigine therapy is greatest when high doses are used, so the initial dose should be low and increased slowly. In addition, about 10% of patients treated with lamotrigine develop a benign skin rash that is difficult to differentiate from early SJS; accordingly, all patients should be advised to discontinue lamotrigine therapy at the first sign of a rash. Other commonly implicated triggers of SJS include allopurinol, sulfamethoxazole, sulfa drugs, and phenobarbital. Other antiepileptic drugs, such as phenytoin, carbamazepine, and ethosuximide, can also cause SJS but are less frequently implicated than lamotrigine.

E) INCORRECT:

Lithium is a mood stabilizer used to treat bipolar disorder. However, cases of SJS attributed to lithium therapy have not been reported. More common adverse effects of lithium therapy include gastrointestinal distress, neurologic symptoms (e.g., slurred speech, ataxia, hand tremors, seizures), nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, thyroid dysfunction (hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism), and teratogenesis (Ebstein anomaly).
questions.hint: This girl's fever, blistering rash, positive Nikolsky sign, and recent medication change are consistent with a diagnosis of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). Toxic epidermal necrolysis is a severe form of this condition that involves > 30% of the skin.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of fever, malaise, sore throat, oral ulcers, and sensitivity to light. She had a urinary tract infection 2 weeks ago that was treated with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. She is sexually active with her partner and uses condoms for contraception. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 12 years. She takes ibuprofen as needed for back pain. She appears ill and fatigued. Her temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F), pulse is 114/min, and blood pressure is 102/64 mm Hg. Physical examination shows injected conjunctivae and purulent discharge. Oral and pelvic examinations show erythema of the mucous membranes. There is no tonsillar swelling or lymphadenopathy. Examination of the skin shows vesicles and tender, erythematous macules with purpuric centers along the jawline, shoulders, and chest. Twelve hours later, the patient develops confluent, purpuric macules, vesicles, bullae, and ulceration on the back, arms, and thighs. When the skin is lightly stroked, the superficial layers of adjacent skin separate. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) can manifest with fever, painful and diffuse skin blistering, and a positive Nikolsky sign, which are seen here. However, because SSSS typically spares mucous membranes, affected individuals do not develop photophobia (from conjunctivitis), sore throat (from pharyngitis), or oral or vaginal ulcers. In addition, this condition most commonly occurs in children < 6 years of age, and the onset of blisters is typically preceded by a staphylococcal infection (e.g., impetigo), which is not consistent with this patient's presentation.
Image Description:

Perioral, cervical and axillary reddening of the skin is visible, resulting in a scalded appearance on this child's face. In some areas, the superficial epidermal layer is detached (e.g., on the chin). On the right side of the neck, several flaccid blisters can be seen. The lips appear dry, with several rhagades in the corners of the mouth.

B) INCORRECT:

Bullous pemphigoid (BP) can be triggered by sulfonamide drugs (e.g., trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole). It can also manifest with vesicles and bullae, which are seen here. However, because BP typically spares mucous membranes, affected individuals do not develop photophobia (from conjunctivitis), sore throat (from pharyngitis), or oral or vaginal ulcers. In addition, BP does not usually cause fever, a rash of varying morphology (e.g., macules, vesicles, and targetoid lesions), or a positive Nikolsky sign. Moreover, peak incidence of BP is among patients > 60 years of age.
Image Description:

Tense blisters, erosions, and crusts on erythematous skin are visible on the knee.

These findings are consistent with bullous pemphigoid.

C) CORRECT:

Fever, mucositis, skin tenderness, and a blistering rash that develop within 1 month of exposure to a triggering medication, such as a sulfonamide drug (e.g., trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole), are consistent with a diagnosis of toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). This condition is a severe form of Stevens-Johnson syndrome characterized by the involvement of > 30% body surface area. Skin lesions typically start on the face and trunk before spreading symmetrically to other areas. These lesions begin as painful, targetoid lesions (e.g., erythematous macules with purpuric centers) that progress to form vesicles and bullae before eventually causing extensive, full-thickness epidermal necrosis and sloughing of the skin at the dermoepidermal junction. Nikolsky sign is typically present. Because TEN also commonly involves the mucous membranes, it can also result in mucositis, ulcers, odynophagia (from pharyngitis), dysphagia (from esophagitis), photophobia (from conjunctivitis), and urogenital complications (e.g., urethritis, genital ulcers). Other common triggers of TEN include allopurinol, certain antiepileptic drugs (e.g., lamotrigine), and infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae).
Image Description:

The trunk and arm show generalized, widespread, extensive necrosis with purple and red erythema, as well as yellow-white exudation. Spots of hemorrhagic, subepidermal tissue can also be seen.

These characteristic findings are distinctive for TEN, a severe form of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS).

D) INCORRECT:

Acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis (AGEP) is a condition that can be triggered by sulfonamide drugs (e.g., trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole) and manifest with fever and a vesicular rash. However, AGEP typically spares the mucous membranes. Therefore, patients do not develop photophobia (from conjunctivitis), sore throat (from pharyngitis), or oral or vaginal ulcers. In addition, AGEP is most commonly associated with the widespread development of pinhead-sized pustules accompanied by edematous erythema with flexural accentuation; bullae are uncommon. Moreover, AGEP typically manifests within a few days of drug exposure.

E) INCORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris (PV) can manifest with painful vesicles and bullae on mucous membranes and the skin, as well as a positive Nikolsky sign. It can be triggered by NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen), which this patient has been taking. However, PV does not typically cause fever or a rash of varying morphology (e.g., macules, vesicles, and targetoid lesions). In addition, peak incidence of PV is among patients 40–60 years of age.
Image Description:

Photograph of the right temporal region in a male patient

A large (approx. 6–8 cm), eroded, and inflamed lesion is visible with a slightly crusted and irregular border. There also appear to be small areas of bleeding around the left border of the lesion.

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

F) INCORRECT:

Erythema multiforme (EM) is a condition that can be triggered by sulfonamide drugs (e.g., trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole). It can also manifest with an acute rash of varying morphology (e.g., macules, vesicles, and targetoid lesions) that is symmetrically distributed. EM with severe mucosal involvement and systemic symptoms (e.g., fever) is called erythema multiforme major. Unlike the rash seen here, EM skin lesions are typically painless and most commonly begin on the backs of the hands and feet before spreading proximally to involve other areas, including the palms and soles. In addition, EM is most commonly triggered by infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae); drug triggers account for < 10% of cases.
Image Description:

Multiple circular lesions with a central papule and raised edges (also called “target lesions”), surrounded by a lighter edematous area, are visible on the anterior aspect of the thighs.

This is the typical appearance of erythema multiforme.
questions.hint: This patient's fever, mucositis, skin tenderness, blistering, and positive Nikolsky sign are caused by an immune-mediated mucocutaneous reaction that was most likely induced by recent sulfonamide therapy (trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole).

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 59 years 
Gender: F, self-identified 
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified 
Site of Care: emergency department
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “This rash is killing me.”
History of Present Illness:

3-day history of a painful, blistering rash

rash started on trunk and spread to face and extremities
1-week history of fever and sore throat
was prescribed a new long-term medication 2 weeks ago by her primary care provider
no recent sick contacts

Past Medical History:

type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by peripheral neuropathy
hypertension
hyperlipidemia
bipolar disorder
breast cancer treated with total mastectomy

Medications:

atorvastatin
captopril
dulaglutide
lamotrigine
letrozole
metformin
over-the-counter ibuprofen prn for fever and sore throat

Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:

father: type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension
maternal grandmother: breast cancer diagnosed age 56 years 

Psychosocial History:
does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs 
Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


39.0 °C(102.2°F)
98/min
16/min
132/88 mm Hg
96% on RA

175 cm(5 ft 9 in)

100 kg(220 lb)
32.5 kg/m2



Appearance: appears uncomfortable
Skin: numerous coalescing bullae with epidermal detachment on the face, trunk, and extremities; a new blister starts to form when lateral pressure is applied to healthy-appearing skin at the edge of an existing bulla
HEENT: hemorrhagic erosions on the hard palate and buccal mucosa; conjunctival injection
Neck: no jugular venous distention
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rhythm
Abdominal: soft, nontender, nondistended
Neurologic: fully oriented


Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced pemphigus due to thiol-containing drugs (e.g., captopril) typically manifests as pemphigus foliaceus. This condition can result in a blistering rash and a positive Nikolsky sign but, unlike pemphigus vulgaris, does not involve the mucosa. Moreover, neither pemphigus vulgaris nor pemphigus foliaceus is associated with a prodromal fever. ACE inhibitors (e.g., captopril) are not a known cause of SJS. Thiazides, which are structurally similar to antibacterial sulfonamides, were once believed to cause SJS but recent studies have shown no significant link.
Image Description:

The erythematous skin of the face is covered with yellowish scales and crusts; the lips appear unaffected.

The diagnosis of pemphigus foliaceus was confirmed via skin biopsy and positive direct immunofluorescence. Unlike pemphigus vulgaris, which affects only the lower epidermal layers, including of the mucous membranes, but causes neither scaling nor crusting, pemphigus foliaceus is a blistering disease of the upper epidermal layers, resulting in the features seen here but not affecting the mucous membranes.

B) INCORRECT:

Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor used in the treatment of estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. Typical adverse effects include hot flashes, night sweats, vaginal dryness, myalgias, arthralgias, and an increased risk of osteoporosis. Letrozole is not a known cause of SJS.

C) INCORRECT:

NSAID-induced SJS usually occurs with oxicam NSAIDs (e.g., piroxicam, tenoxicam) rather than with ibuprofen. In addition, ibuprofen was not started until after the onset of prodromal symptoms (e.g., fever, sore throat) of SJS.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists (e.g., dulaglutide) can rarely cause serious type 1 hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., anaphylaxis) but have not been identified to be a cause of SJS. Sulfonylureas, which are structurally similar to antibacterial sulfonamides, were once believed to cause SJS but recent studies have shown no significant link.

E) INCORRECT:

Adverse effects of statins (e.g., atorvastatin) include headaches, gastrointestinal symptoms, elevated LFTs, myalgias, and statin-associated myopathy. Statins are not a known cause of SJS.

F) CORRECT:

Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is used to treat bipolar disorder. It is one of the most commonly implicated triggers of SJS. Most cases of SJS develop within 2–8 weeks of initiating the offending medication. The risk of developing SJS induced by lamotrigine therapy is greatest when high doses are used, so the initial dose should be low and increased slowly. In addition, about 10% of patients treated with lamotrigine develop a benign skin rash that is difficult to differentiate from early SJS; accordingly, all patients should be advised to discontinue lamotrigine therapy at the first sign of a rash. Certain antiepileptic drugs such as phenytoin, phenobarbital, and carbamazepine can also cause SJS but are less frequently implicated than lamotrigine. Other commonly implicated triggers of SJS include certain sulfa drugs (e.g., sulfamethoxazole, sulfasalazine), certain antiretroviral drugs (e.g., nevirapine), oxicam NSAIDs (e.g., piroxicam), and allopurinol.
questions.hint: This patient's prodromal fever, blistering rash, positive Nikolsky sign, and recent medication change are consistent with a diagnosis of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). Toxic epidermal necrolysis is a severe form of this condition that involves > 30% of the skin.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a new cutaneous eruption and chapped lips. Her symptoms started 2 days ago and have continued to worsen. Her recent medical history includes a newly diagnosed seizure disorder, for which she takes an antiepileptic medication.
Her temperature is 40.5°C, her heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals extensive erosions of the lips and oral mucosa with conjunctival injection. On the face, neck, trunk, and extremities, there are large areas of dusky, confluent erythema associated with both intact and ruptured bullae (figure). The eruption involves approximately 40% of her body-surface area. No lymphadenopathy is noted on examination.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fixed drug eruption is most commonly characterized by a solitary, oval violaceous patch on the skin or mucosa that often recurs in the same anatomic location after each exposure to culprit medications. Multiple patches may occur, but this is rare.

B) INCORRECT:

Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) is a severe cutaneous reaction characterized by fevers, facial swelling, and variable erythematous dermatitis. Patients often exhibit lymphadenopathy. Laboratory abnormalities include peripheral eosinophilia or atypical lymphocytosis and elevations in liver function test results. Notably, these laboratory findings are not always present in cases of DRESS and can also be seen in SJS-TEN, so the diagnosis is primarily clinical. The clinical finding of “dusky centers” indicates incipient skin necrosis and detachment, a finding more commonly seen in SJS-TEN. Mucosal involvement can occur in DRESS but is less severe than in SJS-TEN. When in doubt, skin biopsy can assist the clinician in arriving at the correct diagnosis. Full-thickness epidermal necrosis would be seen in SJS-TEN.

C) CORRECT:

Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) is a severe cutaneous reaction, often to a medication, with significant potential for morbidity and mortality. Key clinical features of TEN include fever, mucosal involvement, malaise, and dusky patches representing full-thickness skin necrosis, associated with blistering or imminent blistering involving >30% of the body-surface area. Stevens-Johnson syndrome has similar clinical features but involves <10% of body-surface area; SJS-TEN involves 10% to 30% of body-surface area. In all three conditions, the dusky patches may be more difficult to note on skin of color than on lighter skin. Potentially implicated medications in all three diagnoses include antibiotics, aromatic anticonvulsants (carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital), lamotrigine, allopurinol, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, and antiretrovirals.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient who recently started a new medication and presents with fever, eye changes, mucosal changes, and dusky patches on >30% of body-surface area is toxic epidermal necrolysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis, a severe cutaneous reaction that occurs quickly after drug exposure (24 to 72 hours), is characterized by erythema with minute pustules but not full-thickness skin necrosis in widespread areas. Mucosal involvement is less common.

E) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome has similar clinical features to toxic epidermal necrolysis, which this patient has, but involves <10% of body-surface area.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a widespread rash. He reports that 2 days ago he had a sore throat and what felt like a fever. Yesterday, his eyes became irritated and red, and he developed a few pruritic skin lesions. Today, his skin is painful in some areas, and the rash has worsened. He reports no personal or family history of skin problems or allergies. His current medications are phenytoin, which he started 3 weeks ago for a seizure disorder, and intermittent ibuprofen for occasional knee pain.
On physical examination, he appears uncomfortable and has a temperature of 37.8°C, a heart rate of 115 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg. His conjunctivae are injected, and there are scattered small vesicles on the mucosal lips. Skin examination reveals scattered lesions over 8% to 9% of his body, most intense and coalescent on the flanks (figure). The Nikolsky sign is positive.
A complete blood count reveals a leukocyte count of 16,500 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000), with 80% polymorphonuclear cells and 2% eosinophils. Electrolyte levels are within normal limits. The aspartate and alanine aminotransferase levels are 71 and 62 U/liter, respectively (0–35).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Symmetric drug-related intertriginous and flexural exanthem

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s constellation of physical findings is consistent with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), a severe mucocutaneous reaction that is usually related to medication use.

SJS is characterized by widespread epithelial apoptosis and necrosis that lead to mucositis and epidermal loss. Many affected patients exhibit a prodrome of fever, malaise, and upper respiratory symptoms followed by mucosal inflammation and then skin signs that characteristically include dusky, painful blisters and erosions. Blisters may be advanced laterally by applying a shearing pressure on the skin with a finger (Nikolsky sign). The classic cutaneous lesion of SJS is an atypical target lesion, a macule with only two zones of erythema: an outer rim of pink inflammation and a central, bright-red or dusky area of severe epidermal damage and death. The rim will blanch with pressure, but the central area will not.

The clinical features of SJS are the same as those seen in toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) but affect a smaller percentage of body-surface area: <10% in SJS versus >30% in TEN. Those with epidermal detachment of 10% to 30% of body-surface area are considered to have SJS-TEN overlap.

The medications most frequently implicated in SJS are allopurinol, carbamazepine, lamotrigine, nevirapine, oxicam nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, phenobarbital, phenytoin, sulfamethoxazole, and sulfasalazine. When SJS or TEN is suspected, potential culprit medications should be discontinued immediately, and the patient should never be rechallenged with them. In this particular case, the patient should discontinue both phenytoin and ibuprofen, as these drugs are both associated with relatively high rates of severe drug reactions, including SJS and TEN.

Key learning point: The presence of conjunctival and oral mucosal inflammation coupled with dusky, painful, blistering skin lesions suggests a diagnosis of Stevens-Johnson syndrome.
Image Description:

Area below the popliteal fossa of the right knee (image mirrored and rotated left by 90°) of an 8-month-old infant 2 weeks after primary vaccination

Irregularly shaped, partially confluent, erythematous macules with bullae are visible.

Patient history suggests Stevens-Johnson syndrome triggered by vaccination.

B) INCORRECT:

Urticarial drug eruptions would not manifest with skin pain, vesicles, bullae and erosions, and a positive Nikolsky sign.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis (AGEP) is characterized by fever, leukocytosis, and the abrupt onset of innumerable pinpoint non-folliculocentric fine papules and papulopustules, which may initially be concentrated in skin folds and flexural areas. Onset typically occurs within 24 to 48 hours after initial drug exposure. Mucosal involvement is less common in AGEP than in SJS or TEN.

D) INCORRECT:

Generalized bullous fixed drug eruption (GBFDE) is characterized by oval patches that have central dusky or purple areas of erythema and that recur repeatedly at the same sites with repeated exposure to the same medication. GBFDE may affect the mucosa, but this patient lacks the key feature of recurrent lesions at the same sites.

E) INCORRECT:

Symmetric drug-related intertriginous and flexural exanthem (SDRIFE) is characterized by bright erythema of the gluteal/perianal area, axillae, and inguinal creases in the absence of systemic illness or toxicity.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a widespread rash. Her father reports that 2 days ago she had a sore throat and what felt like a fever. Yesterday, her eyes became irritated and red, and she developed a few pruritic skin lesions. Today, her skin is painful in some areas, and the rash has worsened. There is no personal or family history of skin problems or allergies. Her only current medication is phenytoin, which was started 3 weeks ago for a newly diagnosed seizure disorder. She has also been taking intermittent ibuprofen for headaches.
On physical examination, she appears uncomfortable and has a temperature of 37.8°C, a heart rate of 115 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg. Her conjunctivae are injected, and there are scattered small vesicles on the mucosal lips. Skin examination reveals scattered lesions over 8% to 9% of her body, most intense and coalescent on the flanks (figure). The Nikolsky sign is positive.
A complete blood count reveals a leukocyte count of 16,500 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–13,500), with 80% polymorphonuclear cells and 2% eosinophils. Electrolyte levels are within normal limits. The aspartate and alanine aminotransferase levels are 71 and 62 U/liter, respectively (5–35).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Symmetric drug-related intertriginous and flexural exanthem

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Generalized bullous fixed drug eruption (GBFDE) is characterized by oval patches that have central dusky or purple areas of erythema and that recur repeatedly at the same sites with repeated exposure to the same medication. GBFDE may affect the mucosa, but this patient lacks the key feature of recurrent lesions at the same sites.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s constellation of physical findings is consistent with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), a severe mucocutaneous reaction that is usually related to medication use.

SJS is characterized by widespread epithelial apoptosis and necrosis that lead to mucositis and epidermal loss. Many affected patients exhibit a prodrome of fever, malaise, and upper respiratory symptoms followed by mucosal inflammation and then skin signs that characteristically include dusky, painful blisters and erosions. Blisters may be advanced laterally by applying a shearing pressure on the skin with a finger (Nikolsky sign). The classic cutaneous lesion of SJS is an atypical target lesion, a macule with only two zones of erythema: an outer rim of pink inflammation and a central, bright-red or dusky area of severe epidermal damage and death. The rim will blanch with pressure, but the central area will not.

The clinical features of SJS are the same as those seen in toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) but affect a smaller percentage of body-surface area: <10% in SJS versus >30% in TEN. Those with epidermal detachment of 10% to 30% of body-surface area are considered to have SJS-TEN overlap.

The medications most frequently implicated in SJS are allopurinol, carbamazepine, lamotrigine, nevirapine, oxicam nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, phenobarbital, phenytoin, sulfamethoxazole, and sulfasalazine. When SJS or TEN is suspected, potential culprit medications should be discontinued immediately, and the patient should never be rechallenged with them. In this particular case, the patient should discontinue both phenytoin and ibuprofen, as these drugs are both associated with relatively high rates of severe drug reactions, including SJS and TEN.

Key learning point: The presence of conjunctival and oral mucosal inflammation coupled with dusky, painful, blistering skin lesions suggests a diagnosis of Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Symmetric drug-related intertriginous and flexural exanthem (SDRIFE) is characterized by bright erythema of the gluteal/perianal area, axillae, and inguinal creases in the absence of systemic illness or toxicity.

D) INCORRECT:

Urticarial drug eruptions would not manifest with skin pain, vesicles, bullae and erosions, and a positive Nikolsky sign.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis (AGEP) is characterized by fever, leukocytosis, and the abrupt onset of innumerable pinpoint non-folliculocentric fine papules and papulopustules, which may initially be concentrated in skin folds and flexural areas. Onset typically occurs within 24 to 48 hours after initial drug exposure. Mucosal involvement is less common in AGEP than in SJS or TEN.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a new cutaneous eruption and chapped lips. Her symptoms started 2 days ago and have continued to worsen. Her recent medical history includes a newly diagnosed seizure disorder, for which she takes an antiepileptic medication.
Her temperature is 40.5°C, her heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals extensive erosions of the lips and oral mucosa with conjunctival injection. On the face, neck, trunk, and extremities, there are large areas of dusky, confluent erythema associated with both intact and ruptured bullae (figure). The eruption involves approximately 40% of her body-surface area. No lymphadenopathy is noted on examination.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) is a severe cutaneous reaction characterized by fevers, facial swelling, and variable erythematous dermatitis. Patients often exhibit lymphadenopathy. Laboratory abnormalities include peripheral eosinophilia or atypical lymphocytosis and elevations in liver function test results. Notably, these laboratory findings are not always present in cases of DRESS and can also be seen in SJS-TEN, so the diagnosis is primarily clinical. The clinical finding of “dusky centers” indicates incipient skin necrosis and detachment, a finding more commonly seen in SJS-TEN. Mucosal involvement can occur in DRESS but is less severe than in SJS-TEN. When in doubt, skin biopsy can assist the clinician in arriving at the correct diagnosis. Full-thickness epidermal necrosis would be seen in SJS-TEN.

B) CORRECT:

Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) is a severe cutaneous reaction, often to a medication, with significant potential for morbidity and mortality. Key clinical features of TEN include fever, mucosal involvement, malaise, and dusky patches representing full-thickness skin necrosis, associated with blistering or imminent blistering involving >30% of the body-surface area. Stevens-Johnson syndrome has similar clinical features but involves <10% of body-surface area; SJS-TEN involves 10% to 30% of body-surface area. In all three conditions, the dusky patches may be more difficult to note on skin of color than on lighter skin. Potentially implicated medications in all three diagnoses include antibiotics, aromatic anticonvulsants (carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital), lamotrigine, allopurinol, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, and antiretrovirals.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient who recently started a new medication and presents with fever, eye changes, mucosal changes, and dusky patches on >30% of body-surface area is toxic epidermal necrolysis.

C) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome has similar clinical features to TEN but involves <10% of body-surface area.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis, a severe cutaneous reaction that occurs quickly after drug exposure (24 to 72 hours), is characterized by erythema with minute pustules but not full-thickness skin necrosis in widespread areas. Mucosal involvement is less common.

E) INCORRECT:

Fixed drug eruption is most commonly characterized by a solitary, oval violaceous patch on the skin or mucosa that often recurs in the same anatomic location after each exposure to culprit medications. Multiple patches may occur, but this is rare.

questions.text: One week after starting a new medication, a 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of a painful, blistering rash. She has a history of bipolar disorder. Her temperature is 39°C (102°F). Physical examination shows numerous coalescing bullae with epidermal detachment covering the face, trunk, and extremities. There are hemorrhagic erosions on the hard palate and buccal mucosa. When lateral pressure is applied to healthy-appearing skin at the edge of a bulla, a blister starts to form. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Quetiapine is an atypical antipsychotic that is used with first-line mood stabilizers to treat refractory bipolar disorder. However, cases of SJS attributed to quetiapine therapy have not been reported. More common adverse effects of quetiapine therapy include hyperprolactinemia, weight gain, hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, prolonged QT interval, and extrapyramidal symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is sometimes used in conjunction with other agents to treat refractory bipolar disorder. However, cases of SJS attributed to topiramate therapy have not been reported. More common adverse effects of topiramate therapy include glaucoma, weight loss, nephrolithiasis, and cognitive impairment.

C) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is used to treat bipolar disorder. However, valproic acid is an extremely rare cause of SJS. More common adverse effects of valproic acid therapy include hepatic necrosis, pancreatitis, drug interactions due to CYP450 inhibition, weight gain, and gastrointestinal distress.

D) CORRECT:

Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is used to treat bipolar disorder. It is one of the most commonly implicated triggers of SJS. Most cases of SJS develop within 2–8 weeks of initiating the offending medication. The risk of developing SJS induced by lamotrigine therapy is greatest when high doses are used, so the initial dose should be low and increased slowly. In addition, about 10% of patients treated with lamotrigine develop a benign skin rash that is difficult to differentiate from early SJS; accordingly, all patients should be advised to discontinue lamotrigine therapy at the first sign of a rash. Other commonly implicated triggers of SJS include allopurinol, sulfamethoxazole, sulfa drugs, and phenobarbital. Other antiepileptic drugs, such as phenytoin, carbamazepine, and ethosuximide, can also cause SJS but are less frequently implicated than lamotrigine.

E) INCORRECT:

Lithium is a mood stabilizer used to treat bipolar disorder. However, cases of SJS attributed to lithium therapy have not been reported. More common adverse effects of lithium therapy include gastrointestinal distress, neurologic symptoms (e.g., slurred speech, ataxia, hand tremors, seizures), nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, thyroid dysfunction (hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism), and teratogenesis (Ebstein anomaly).
questions.hint: This girl's fever, blistering rash, positive Nikolsky sign, and recent medication change are consistent with a diagnosis of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). Toxic epidermal necrolysis is a severe form of this condition that involves > 30% of the skin.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of malaise, dysuria, blurred vision, and a painful, itchy rash. One week ago, she was diagnosed with trigeminal neuralgia and started on a new medicine. She has a fever. Physical examination shows conjunctival injection and ulceration on the tongue and palate. There is no lymphadenopathy. Examination of the skin shows confluent annular, erythematous macules, bullae, and desquamation of the palms and soles. The epidermis separates when the skin is lightly stroked. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a rare yet serious adverse effect of carbamazepine, as well as many other drugs (e.g., phenytoin, lamotrigine, and phenobarbital). It initially manifests with fever and flu-like symptoms (e.g., chills and myalgias). The classic cutaneous manifestation consists of painful, erythematous, annular macules with pruritic centers that begin on the face and thorax and spread symmetrically to the extremities, which are accompanied by stomatitis, mucositis, conjunctivitis, and/or corneal ulceration. Physical examination often shows a positive Nikolsky sign, as seen in this patient. The skin desquamation may progress to involve large areas of the skin. Involvement of > 30% of the total body surface area is referred to as toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), whereas involvement of 10–30% is considered SJS/TEN overlap. Treatment of SJS includes discontinuation of the offending drug and supportive therapy similar to that of burns (fluid resuscitation, wound management, antibiotics in case of infection). Cyclosporine may slow SJS progression.

Key learning point: Stevens-Johnson syndrome is a severe mucocutaneous reaction, often triggered by medications, characterized by painful skin lesions, mucosal involvement, and a positive Nikolsky sign.
Image Description:

Back, buttocks, thighs, and legs of an 8-month-old infant 2 weeks after primary vaccination

Irregularly shaped, partially confluent, erythematous macules with bullae are visible.

Patient history suggests Stevens-Johnson syndrome triggered by vaccination.

B) INCORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris (PV) classically manifests with cutaneous flaccid bullae that can affect the oral mucosa but spare the palms and soles. The bullae have a positive Nikolsky sign and tend to rupture easily, leading to significant pain and bleeding; however, pruritus would not be expected following rupture. Moreover, it would be very rare for PV to arise following treatment with carbamazepine.
Image Description:

Multiple ruptured blisters with surrounding erythema are visible. A single intact blister can be seen in the center of the image.

This finding is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris, but histopathology is required to confirm the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced lupus is associated with a variety of drugs, including sulfa-drugs, antiepileptics (e.g. carbamazepine or phenytoin), and TNF-α blockers. The condition initially manifests with systemic symptoms (e,g., fevers, myalgias, and arthralgias) and may cause serositis (e.g. pleuritis and pericarditis) or hematologic abnormalities (e.g., anemia, leukopenia, and/or thrombocytopenia). Cutaneous manifestations are less common in drug-induced lupus than in idiopathic lupus. When present, the rash associated with drug-induced lupus takes the form of large, erythematous patches rather than the bullae with a positive Nikolsky sign seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) is a rare drug-induced hypersensitivity reaction that is caused by a variety of drugs, including carbamazepine. While it manifests with fever, affected patients also have facial edema and lymphadenopathy, neither of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, the rash is usually a morbilliform eruption that quickly evolves into a diffuse, confluent rash involving > 50% of the body surface area. The presence of bullae and a positive Nikolsky sign are inconsistent with DRESS syndrome.
Image Description:

Facial erythema and edema are visible, sparing only the periorbital region. The erythema, especially around the mouth, has an eczematous appearance.

Facial edema is a common clinical feature in DRESS, but also occurs in many other conditions. The triad of high fever, extensive skin rash, and organ involvement should raise concern for DRESS.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) is caused by S. aureus exfoliative toxin. SSSS manifests with systemic symptoms (e.g., fever and malaise) and diffuse, flaccid bullae along the flexural surfaces, hands, feet, and buttock; the Nikolsky sign is typically positive. However, SSSS is most often seen in the pediatric population following a staphylococcal infection (e.g., impetigo), which this adult patient has no history of. Finally, mucosal involvement, as seen in this patient, would be very unusual.
Image Description:

Perioral, cervical and axillary reddening of the skin is visible, resulting in a scalded appearance on this child's face. In some areas, the superficial epidermal layer is detached (e.g., on the chin). On the right side of the neck, several flaccid blisters can be seen. The lips appear dry, with several rhagades in the corners of the mouth.
questions.hint: The first-line therapy for trigeminal neuralgia is carbamazepine, which is the most likely trigger of this patient's mucocutaneous immune reaction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of fever, malaise, sore throat, oral ulcers, and sensitivity to light. She had a urinary tract infection 2 weeks ago that was treated with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. Her temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F), pulse is 114/min, and blood pressure is 102/64 mm Hg. Physical examination shows injected conjunctivae and purulent discharge. Oral and pelvic examinations show erythema of the mucous membranes. Examination of the skin shows vesicles and tender, erythematous macules with purpuric centers along the jawline, shoulders, and chest. Twelve hours later, the patient develops confluent, purpuric macules, vesicles, bullae, and ulceration on the back, arms, and thighs. When the skin is lightly stroked, the superficial layers of adjacent skin separate. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) can manifest with fever, painful and diffuse skin blistering, and a positive Nikolsky sign, which are seen here. However, because SSSS typically spares mucous membranes, affected individuals do not develop photophobia (from conjunctivitis), sore throat (from pharyngitis), or oral or vaginal ulcers. In addition, this condition most commonly occurs in children < 6 years of age, and the onset of blisters is typically preceded by a staphylococcal infection (e.g., impetigo), which is not consistent with this patient's presentation.
Image Description:

Perioral, cervical and axillary reddening of the skin is visible, resulting in a scalded appearance on this child's face. In some areas, the superficial epidermal layer is detached (e.g., on the chin). On the right side of the neck, several flaccid blisters can be seen. The lips appear dry, with several rhagades in the corners of the mouth.

B) INCORRECT:

Bullous pemphigoid (BP) can be triggered by sulfonamide drugs (e.g., trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole). It can also manifest with vesicles and bullae, which are seen here. However, because BP typically spares mucous membranes, affected individuals do not develop photophobia (from conjunctivitis), sore throat (from pharyngitis), or oral or vaginal ulcers. In addition, BP does not usually cause fever, a rash of varying morphology (e.g., macules, vesicles, and targetoid lesions), or a positive Nikolsky sign. Moreover, peak incidence of BP is among patients > 60 years of age.
Image Description:

Tense blisters, erosions, and crusts on erythematous skin are visible on the knee.

These findings are consistent with bullous pemphigoid.

C) CORRECT:

Fever, mucositis, skin tenderness, and a blistering rash that develop within 1 month of exposure to a triggering medication, such as a sulfonamide drug (e.g., trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole), are consistent with a diagnosis of toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). This condition is a severe form of Stevens-Johnson syndrome characterized by the involvement of > 30% body surface area. Skin lesions typically start on the face and trunk before spreading symmetrically to other areas. These lesions begin as painful, targetoid lesions (e.g., erythematous macules with purpuric centers) that progress to form vesicles and bullae before eventually causing extensive, full-thickness epidermal necrosis and sloughing of the skin at the dermoepidermal junction. Nikolsky sign is typically present. Because TEN also commonly involves the mucous membranes, it can also result in mucositis, ulcers, odynophagia (from pharyngitis), dysphagia (from esophagitis), photophobia (from conjunctivitis), and urogenital complications (e.g., urethritis, genital ulcers). Other common triggers of TEN include allopurinol, certain antiepileptic drugs (e.g., lamotrigine), and infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae).
Image Description:

The trunk and arm show generalized, widespread, extensive necrosis with purple and red erythema, as well as yellow-white exudation. Spots of hemorrhagic, subepidermal tissue can also be seen.

These characteristic findings are distinctive for TEN, a severe form of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS).

D) INCORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris (PV) can manifest with painful vesicles and bullae on mucous membranes and the skin, as well as a positive Nikolsky sign. It can be triggered by NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen), which this patient has been taking. However, PV does not typically cause fever or a rash of varying morphology (e.g., macules, vesicles, and targetoid lesions). In addition, peak incidence of PV is among patients 40–60 years of age.
Image Description:

Photograph of the right temporal region in a male patient

A large (approx. 6–8 cm), eroded, and inflamed lesion is visible with a slightly crusted and irregular border. There also appear to be small areas of bleeding around the left border of the lesion.

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

E) INCORRECT:

Erythema multiforme (EM) is a condition that can be triggered by sulfonamide drugs (e.g., trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole). It can also manifest with an acute rash of varying morphology (e.g., macules, vesicles, and targetoid lesions) that is symmetrically distributed. EM with severe mucosal involvement and systemic symptoms (e.g., fever) is called erythema multiforme major. Unlike the rash seen here, EM skin lesions are typically painless and most commonly begin on the backs of the hands and feet before spreading proximally to involve other areas, including the palms and soles. In addition, EM is most commonly triggered by infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae); drug triggers account for < 10% of cases.
Image Description:

Multiple circular lesions with a central papule and raised edges (also called “target lesions”), surrounded by a lighter edematous area, are visible on the anterior aspect of the thighs.

This is the typical appearance of erythema multiforme.
questions.hint: This patient's fever, mucositis, skin tenderness, blistering, and positive Nikolsky sign are caused by an immune-mediated mucocutaneous reaction that was most likely induced by recent sulfonamide therapy (trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole).

questions.text: You are seeing a 56-year-old woman in the emergency department with a 3-day history of malaise, dysuria, blurred vision, and a painful, itchy rash. One week ago, she was diagnosed with trigeminal neuralgia and started on a new medication. She has a fever. On examination, there is conjunctival injection and ulceration of the tongue and palate. There is no lymphadenopathy. Skin examination reveals confluent annular, erythematous macules, bullae, and desquamation of the palms and soles. The epidermis separates when the skin is lightly stroked. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris (PV) classically manifests with cutaneous flaccid bullae that can affect the oral mucosa but spare the palms and soles. The bullae have a positive Nikolsky sign and tend to rupture easily, leading to significant pain and bleeding; however, pruritus would not be expected following rupture. Moreover, it would be very rare for PV to arise following treatment with carbamazepine.

B) INCORRECT:

Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) is a rare drug-induced hypersensitivity reaction that is caused by a variety of drugs, including carbamazepine. While it manifests with fever, affected patients also have facial edema and lymphadenopathy, neither of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, the rash is usually a morbilliform eruption that quickly evolves into a diffuse, confluent rash involving > 50% of the body surface area. The presence of bullae and a positive Nikolsky sign are inconsistent with DRESS syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) is caused by S. aureus exfoliative toxin. SSSS manifests with systemic symptoms (e.g., fever and malaise) and diffuse, flaccid bullae along the flexural surfaces, hands, feet, and buttock; the Nikolsky sign is typically positive. However, SSSS is most often seen in the pediatric population following a staphylococcal infection (e.g., impetigo), which this adult patient has no history of. Finally, mucosal involvement, as seen in this patient, would be very unusual.

D) CORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a rare yet serious adverse effect of carbamazepine, as well as many other drugs (e.g., phenytoin, lamotrigine, and phenobarbital). It initially manifests with fever and flu-like symptoms (e.g., chills and myalgias). The classic cutaneous manifestation consists of painful, erythematous, annular macules with pruritic centers that begin on the face and thorax and spread symmetrically to the extremities, which are accompanied by stomatitis, mucositis, conjunctivitis, and/or corneal ulceration. Physical examination often shows a positive Nikolsky sign, as seen in this patient. The skin desquamation may progress to involve large areas of the skin. Involvement of > 30% of the total body surface area is referred to as toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), whereas involvement of 10–30% is considered SJS/TEN overlap. Treatment of SJS includes discontinuation of the offending drug and supportive therapy similar to that of burns (fluid resuscitation, wound management, antibiotics in case of infection). Cyclosporine may slow SJS progression.

Key learning point: Stevens-Johnson syndrome is a severe mucocutaneous reaction, often triggered by medications, characterized by painful skin lesions, mucosal involvement, and a positive Nikolsky sign.
Image Description:

Back, buttocks, thighs, and legs of an 8-month-old infant 2 weeks after primary vaccination

Irregularly shaped, partially confluent, erythematous macules with bullae are visible.

Patient history suggests Stevens-Johnson syndrome triggered by vaccination.

E) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced lupus is associated with a variety of drugs, including sulfa-drugs, antiepileptics (e.g. carbamazepine or phenytoin), and TNF-α blockers. The condition initially manifests with systemic symptoms (e,g., fevers, myalgias, and arthralgias) and may cause serositis (e.g. pleuritis and pericarditis) or hematologic abnormalities (e.g., anemia, leukopenia, and/or thrombocytopenia). Cutaneous manifestations are less common in drug-induced lupus than in idiopathic lupus. When present, the rash associated with drug-induced lupus takes the form of large, erythematous patches rather than the bullae with a positive Nikolsky sign seen in this patient.
questions.hint: The first-line therapy for trigeminal neuralgia is carbamazepine, which is the most likely trigger of this patient's mucocutaneous immune reaction.

questions.text: You are seeing a 16-year-old girl who is brought to the emergency department by her mother with a painful, blistering rash that developed one week after starting a new medication. She has a history of bipolar disorder. Her temperature is 39°C. On examination, there are numerous coalescing bullae with epidermal detachment involving the face, trunk, and extremities. Hemorrhagic erosions are present on the hard palate and buccal mucosa. When lateral pressure is applied to healthy-appearing skin at the edge of a bulla, a blister forms. Which one of the following drugs is most likely responsible for her current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Quetiapine is a second-generation antipsychotic that is commonly used as a first-line treatment for acute mania and bipolar depression. There have been no reported cases of SJS associated with quetiapine therapy. More common adverse effects of quetiapine therapy include weight gain, hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, prolonged QT interval, extrapyramidal symptoms, and, in some cases, hyperprolactinemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is used to treat bipolar disorder. However, valproic acid is an extremely rare cause of SJS. More common adverse effects of valproic acid therapy include weight gain, gastrointestinal distress, and drug interactions due to CYP450 inhibition. Pancreatitis and hepatic necrosis are other rare but serious side effects of valproic acid.

C) INCORRECT:

Lithium is a mood stabilizer commonly used to treat bipolar disorder. Although extremely rare, it can lead to SJS. However, another medication is a more frequent cause of SJS. More common adverse effects of lithium therapy include gastrointestinal distress and neurological symptoms (e.g., slurred speech, ataxia, hand tremors, seizures). Rare adverse effects include nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, thyroid dysfunction (hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism), and teratogenic effects (e.g., Ebstein anomaly).

D) CORRECT:

Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is used to treat bipolar disorder. It is one of the most commonly implicated triggers of SJS. Most cases of SJS develop within 2–8 weeks of initiating the offending medication. The risk of developing SJS induced by lamotrigine therapy is greatest when high doses are used, so the initial dose should be low and increased slowly. In addition, about 10% of patients treated with lamotrigine develop a benign skin rash that is difficult to differentiate from early SJS; accordingly, all patients should be advised to discontinue lamotrigine therapy at the first sign of a rash. Other commonly implicated triggers of SJS include allopurinol, sulfamethoxazole, sulfa drugs, and phenobarbital. Other antiepileptic drugs, such as phenytoin, carbamazepine, and ethosuximide, can also cause SJS but are less frequently implicated than lamotrigine.

Key learning point: Lamotrigine is a common drug trigger for Stevens-Johnson syndrome, which presents with mucocutaneous blistering and epidermal detachment within weeks of starting therapy.
questions.hint: This girl's fever, blistering rash, positive Nikolsky sign, and recent medication change are consistent with a diagnosis of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). Toxic epidermal necrolysis is a severe form of this condition that involves > 30% of the skin.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 4-day history of fever and malaise. She reports starting minocycline for acne 2 weeks ago. Vital signs are T, 39.2°C (102.6°F); BP, 90/60; P, 115. Physical examination shows widespread painful erythematous lesions with central necrosis and bullae covering approximately 40% of the body surface area, extensive ulcerations of the oral mucosa, and bilateral conjunctival injection. Laboratory studies show a WBC count of 3200/mm3, platelet count of 95,000/mm3, and creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Consult dermatology and prepare for ICU admission

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Widespread epidermal detachment (> 30% body surface area involvement), mucosal lesions, and systemic involvement indicate toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). Tetracyclines (e.g., minocycline) are known triggers of TEN. Immediate dermatology consultation and preparation for ICU admission are essential due to the high risk of mortality from fluid loss, infection, and multiorgan involvement.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum IgE levels are not indicated in the acute management of toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). While TEN involves immune-mediated mechanisms, IgE testing does not aid in diagnosis or immediate treatment decisions.

C) INCORRECT:

The use of systemic corticosteroids in toxic epidermal necrolysis should only be considered after specialist consultation, as evidence supporting their benefit is limited.

D) INCORRECT:

While skin biopsy can support the diagnosis, this patient's clinical presentation is characteristic of toxic epidermal necrolysis. Biopsy should not delay urgent specialist consultation and preparation for ICU admission in patients with obvious systemic involvement.

E) INCORRECT:

Evidence for the benefit of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) in the treatment of toxic epidermal necrolysis is limited. IVIG should only be considered after specialist consultation and should not delay urgent dermatology evaluation and preparation for ICU admission.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a 5-day history of fever and rash that began 3 weeks after starting phenytoin. She appears ill with facial edema and cervical lymphadenopathy. Examination reveals a generalized morbilliform rash covering 60% of her body surface area. Laboratory studies show: WBC 12,800/mm3 with 15% eosinophils, hemoglobin 11.2 g/dL, platelets 145,000/mm3, AST 128 U/L, ALT 156 U/L, and creatinine 1.4 mg/dL (baseline 0.8 mg/dL). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate drug hypersensitivity reactions typically occur within 1 hour of drug exposure and manifest with urticaria, angioedema, bronchospasm, or anaphylaxis. The delayed onset of 3 weeks and presence of facial edema with organ involvement are not consistent with immediate hypersensitivity reactions.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – DRESS syndrome is characterized by delayed onset 2-8 weeks after drug exposure, fever, diffuse morbilliform rash, facial edema, lymphadenopathy, eosinophilia, and internal organ involvement. Facial edema is a common feature of DRESS that is not typically seen in other severe cutaneous adverse reactions. The liver is the most commonly affected organ in DRESS, and kidney involvement can also occur.

C) INCORRECT:

Fixed drug eruption presents as well-defined, erythematous lesions that are often solitary and occur within 8 hours of drug exposure. The generalized morbilliform rash pattern and systemic organ involvement seen in this patient are not characteristic of fixed drug eruption.

D) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome typically has an onset of 1-3 weeks after drug exposure and is characterized by bullous lesions, positive Nikolsky sign, and significant mucosal involvement. This patient's morbilliform rash pattern and lack of bullous lesions make Stevens-Johnson syndrome less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Exanthematous drug eruption presents as a morbilliform rash on the trunk and proximal extremities with typical onset 5-14 days after drug exposure. However, it does not typically involve facial edema, lymphadenopathy, eosinophilia, or internal organ involvement as seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of diffuse rash and oral ulcers. He was started on allopurinol for gout 3 weeks ago. Physical examination shows diffuse red macules on his face and trunk, and several bullae that slough the epidermis when lateral pressure is applied to the skin. His oral examination is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome primarily affects infants and young children, and characteristically spares the mucous membranes, unlike this patient who presents with oral ulcers and desquamation.

B) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis typically presents as intensely pruritic, grouped vesicles on extensor surfaces like the elbows, knees, and buttocks, and is associated with celiac disease, unlike this patient who developed a rash after drug exposure.

C) INCORRECT:

Bullous pemphigoid typically presents with negative Nikolsky sign, unlike in this patient who has a positive Nikolsky sign.

D) INCORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris typically begins with painful oral mucosal erosions that precede cutaneous involvement by weeks to months, unlike in this patient who developed mucocutaneous lesions at the same time.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Stevens-Johnson syndrome is an immune-mediated skin reaction that typically develops 1-3 weeks after drug exposure, consistent with this patient's allopurinol initiation. The characteristic presentation includes painful erythematous macules on the face and trunk that progress to bullae with positive Nikolsky sign, extensive mucosal involvement with oral ulcers and desquamation, and dermal-epidermal dissociation with epidermal sloughing.

questions.text: A 46 year-old woman presents to the emergency department for a 2-day history of rash, oral ulcers, and vaginal erosions. She recently established care with a primary care doctor and she was started on multiple different medications a few weeks ago, including lisinopril for hypertension, lamotrigine for seizures, famotidine for GERD, and metformin and glyburide for diabetes. Her examination is shown. What medication is the most likely cause for her presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lisinopril is not a common cause for Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Famotidine is not a common cause for Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Metformin is not a common cause for Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Lamotrigine is a medication at high-risk for causing Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Glyburide is not a common cause for Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for a rapidly progressing, painful rash over the past 48 hours. He reports a 3-day history of fever and malaise. Three weeks ago, he was started on allopurinol for gout. His temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), his pulse is 120/min, and his blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg. Examination shows diffuse, dusky erythema with large, flaccid bullae and extensive epidermal sloughing affecting approximately 40% of his body surface area. Gentle lateral pressure on the skin results in further separation of the epidermis. He has severe hemorrhagic crusting of the lips and painful oral erosions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) also presents with fever, diffuse erythema, and a positive Nikolsky sign. However, SSSS is caused by an exfoliative toxin and typically affects infants and young children. Critically, mucosal membranes are characteristically spared in SSSS, which contrasts with this patient's severe oral erosions and hemorrhagic lip crusting.

B) INCORRECT:

Erythema multiforme (EM) major is a hypersensitivity reaction that involves mucosal surfaces. However, the characteristic skin lesion in EM is the target lesion, which is not described in this patient. Additionally, EM major is defined by epidermal detachment of < 10% of the body surface area. This patient’s extensive epidermal sloughing affecting 40% of the body surface area is not typical of EM.

C) INCORRECT:

Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune blistering disease that presents with large bullae. However, the bullae are typically tense, not flaccid, and arise on urticarial or erythematous skin. Widespread epidermal sloughing and a positive Nikolsky sign are not characteristic features. Furthermore, the acute systemic toxicity with high fever observed in this patient is atypical for bullous pemphigoid.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), a severe, life-threatening mucocutaneous drug reaction. Key features include a prodrome of fever and malaise, followed by the rapid onset of a painful, dusky erythematous rash that progresses to flaccid bullae and full-thickness epidermal detachment. The diagnosis of TEN is made when > 30% of the body surface area is involved. The positive Nikolsky sign (epidermal separation with gentle pressure) and severe involvement of at least two mucosal surfaces (oral, ocular, or genital) are characteristic. Allopurinol is one of the most common offending agents. Management involves immediate cessation of the causative drug and supportive care in a burn unit.
Image Description:

The trunk and arm show generalized, widespread, extensive necrosis with purple and red erythema, as well as yellow-white exudation. Spots of hemorrhagic, subepidermal tissue can also be seen.

These characteristic findings are distinctive for TEN, a severe form of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS).

E) INCORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune disease that causes flaccid bullae, a positive Nikolsky sign, and often begins with painful oral erosions. However, it is a chronic condition with a more insidious onset, not an acute, fulminant reaction to a new medication. The extensive, rapid epidermal sloughing affecting 40% of the body surface area with systemic signs of toxicity is not typical of pemphigus vulgaris.
questions.hint: The diagnosis of this severe mucocutaneous reaction is determined by the percentage of body surface area affected by epidermal sloughing.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for a painful rash that developed over the past two days. He had a prodrome of fever and malaise for four days prior. The rash began on his trunk and has spread to his face and arms. He reports severe pain with swallowing and eye irritation. His medical history is significant for gout, for which he started allopurinol three weeks ago. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F). Examination shows coalescing erythematous and purpuric macules with dusky centers covering 8% of his body surface area. Gentle lateral pressure results in epidermal sloughing. He has hemorrhagic crusting of the lips and bilateral conjunctivitis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) presents with fever, widespread erythema, and a positive Nikolsky sign. However, it is caused by an exfoliative exotoxin from Staphylococcus aureus, not a drug reaction. SSSS typically affects infants and young children. Crucially, the epidermal cleavage in SSSS is very superficial, and the mucous membranes are characteristically spared, unlike the severe mucosal involvement seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) shares the same pathophysiology and clinical features as Stevens-Johnson syndrome, including the medication trigger, painful rash, positive Nikolsky sign, and mucosal involvement. However, TEN is the most severe form on the disease spectrum and is defined by epidermal detachment involving > 30% of the body surface area. This patient's skin involvement is 8%, which is below the threshold for TEN.

C) CORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a severe, immune-mediated mucocutaneous reaction most often triggered by medications such as allopurinol, anticonvulsants, and sulfonamides. The presentation includes a prodrome of fever and malaise, followed by the eruption of painful, erythematous macules with dusky centers that coalesce. Significant mucosal involvement (e.g., oral, ocular, genital) is a hallmark. A positive Nikolsky sign (epidermal sloughing with gentle pressure) indicates full-thickness epidermal necrosis. The diagnosis of SJS is made when skin detachment covers < 10% of the body surface area. Management requires immediate cessation of the offending drug and supportive care, often in a burn unit or intensive care unit.
Image Description:

Area below the popliteal fossa of the right knee (image mirrored and rotated left by 90°) of an 8-month-old infant 2 weeks after primary vaccination

Irregularly shaped, partially confluent, erythematous macules with bullae are visible.

Patient history suggests Stevens-Johnson syndrome triggered by vaccination.

D) INCORRECT:

Erythema multiforme (EM) major is a mucocutaneous hypersensitivity reaction that can appear similar because of mucosal involvement. However, EM is most commonly triggered by infections, particularly herpes simplex virus. The characteristic skin lesions are classic target lesions with three distinct concentric zones, which are not described in this patient's presentation.

E) INCORRECT:

Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) is a severe adverse drug reaction that can be caused by allopurinol. It typically presents with a morbilliform rash, fever, prominent facial edema, lymphadenopathy, and internal organ involvement (e.g., hepatitis, nephritis), along with eosinophilia. DRESS syndrome does not typically feature the extensive blistering, mucosal erosions, and epidermal sloughing (positive Nikolsky sign) that are the hallmarks of this patient's condition.
questions.hint: The diagnosis of this severe mucocutaneous reaction falls on a spectrum. The specific diagnosis is determined by the percentage of body surface area with epidermal detachment.
